Binary Symmetric Channel

  //   Topics: Coding Theory

A binary symmetric channel is a hypothetical noisy communication channel used to model error probability. We use the binary alphabet {0, 1}, and assume that the probability of an error occuring is independent for each bit transmitted.

The probability of error is p, where \(0 \leq p \leq 1\). In other words, a 0 is changed to a 1 with probability p and vice versa. The probability that an error does not occur is therefore p - 1.

It is expected that \(p \lt {1 \over 2}\), that is, the probability of error is less than 50%. (If this was not the case, we could simply assume that all transmissions are incorrect, and thereby construct an equivalent channel with probability of error 1 - p.)

For more detail, see Wikipedia.
